contextId.information: The words "shook" and "trembled" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how greatly the earth shook. AT: "the land moved back and forth" or "the ground moved up and down" or "there was a violent earthquake" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Guide and teach mean the same thing, to give instruction. AT: "Instruct me to conduct my life by obeying your truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: Guide me into your truth and teach me

contextId.information: The words "forsake" and "abandon" mean the same thing. The writer is emphasizing that he does not want God to leave him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the writer did not speak at all. AT: "I was completely silent" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: I kept silent; I kept back my words

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the intensity of joy. AT: "be very joyful" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These words mean the same thing and emphasize how helpless the writer is. AT: "very needy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

Here the words "hand" and "arm" both refer to God's power. Combined, they emphasize the greatness of God's power. AT: "your great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Since both of these terms are weapons, if your culture knows only one, it is acceptable to use it alone. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two words have basically the same meaning. You cannot trust in money that you get by taking it from other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Both of these phrases refer to man's private or inner thoughts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two phrases have similar meanings. AT: "of all the people who live throughout the earth and across the sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: of all the ends of the earth ... across the sea

contextId.information: Here the words "poor" and "needy" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that he is unable to help himself. AT: "very needy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here the words "poor" and "needy" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that they are unable to help themselves. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how badly the needy suffer. AT: "those who oppress them and hurt them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The second phrase strengthens the first phrase in that Yahweh's glory relates to Yahweh shining brightly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: You shine brightly and reveal your glory

contextId.information: These two phrases have similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

These words mean almost the same thing. The writer uses them both to emphasize that the Israelites did not believe that God would either provide for them or punish evil as he had said he would. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These words mean almost the same thing. The writer uses them both to emphasize that the Israelites did not do for God what they had said they would do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

The words "splendor" and "majesty" have similar meanings and emphasize the greatness of Yahweh's glory. They are described as clothing Yahweh like a garment. AT: "you have splendor and majesty all around you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you are clothed with splendor and majesty

contextId.information: "it is very deep and very wide." The depth and width of the sea emphasizes how large it is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two words have similar meanings and emphasize that he is unable to help himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

The writer repeats the phrase "Not to us" in order to emphasize that they are not worthy to receive the honor that is due only to Yahweh. If necessary, a verbal phrase may be supplied here. AT: "Do not bring honor to us, Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: Not to us, Yahweh, not to us

contextId.information: The writer states the same idea both negatively and positively to emphasize that he will certainly live. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: I will not die, but live

contextId.information: These two words mean almost the same thing. AT: "hate very strongly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two words mean basically the same thing and refer to the miraculous troubles that God had caused in Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
If these two lines are so much the same that the reader will get the wrong meaning, you can translate them as one line. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: I cry out for help to Yahweh ... I plead for Yahweh's favor

contextId.information: If these two lines are so much the same that the reader will get the wrong meaning, you can translate them as one line. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: pour out my lament before him ... I tell him my troubles
